p: The severity of COVID-19 led to its development of drugs or vaccines [ 11]. Although the WHO, FDA, and EMA were part of this community, the Chinese took the lead in developing academia-industry partnerships for the development of therapeutics such as monoclonal antibodies, vaccines, and drugs [ 11]. Such an initiative for vaccine development was recently undertaken by the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), involving several countries [ 12]. In this context, the establishment of a “vaccine bank” by the Canadian Government is commendable [ 13]. Scientists are also considering a drug formulation against post-infection complications [ 14]. Scientists have also taken into consideration previously known antiviral drugs for the treatment of post-infection complications [ 11]. The International Clinical Trials Registry Platform of WHO is dealing with this issue [ 14]. In a WHO project named “Solidarity Trial”, the four most potent existing antiviral drugs were tested against COVID-19 in ten different countries, and the results were reported [ 14]. The formulation of drugs and vaccines requires time, and regulatory agencies such as the FDA and EMA have to ensure their safety throughout the drug development cycle (Fig. 2) before approval [ 13]. This process typically requires almost half a decade [ 15]. The shortest time frame for developing therapeutics is one and a half years, and that for checking their effectiveness is twelve months [ 15, 16]. Currently, many new anti-COVID-19 drugs are in phase I of testing [ 11]. Four antiviral drugs, including hydroxychloroquine (or chloroquine), favipiravir, lopinavir, and remdesivir, have entered phase III or IV. Currently, the CDC is recommending remdesivir as an anti-COVID-19 treatment for COVID-19 patients suffering from pneumonia [ 11].
